In Mass., religious groups split over assisted suicide

Opinions among the state's faiths vary widely on an issue that proponents refer to as “death with dignity” and opponents call “doctor-assisted suicide.” (Globe)

Families welcome a subdued Sept. 11

As the nation observes the 11th anniversary of 9/11, family members of victims welcome a much softer public spotlight on their personal grief than the one cast on them during last year's pervasive 10-year mark. (Globe)

Big, rare cats at King Richard's Faire

The grand felines at King Richard's Faire have taken center stage at the annual fair. But they've also become part of an uproar over endangered species. (Boston Globe)

Down two paths with Joe Paterno

Joe Posnanski's biography of the late legendary head football coach at Penn State University — started before the school's sex abuse scandal unfolded last year — struggles with Joe Paterno's legacy. (Boston Globe)

A teacher’s guide to predators

The new manual for schools underscores a disturbing but intuitive concept: In order to gain access to kids, sexual abusers have to manipulate adults.

Mattapan welcomes health center

The new $34 million home for the Mattapan Community Health Center will double the number of patients the facility serves, officials said.
